text:
This week, we will
consider the special case
of circular motion.

The case where we know that the
motion is exactly constrained
to have a circular geometry.
This will consist of two parts.

First, we will consider the
kinematics of circular motion.

How do we describe the
trajectory, velocity,

and acceleration of a particle
undergoing circular motion?

We will consider
both the simple case

of uniform circular motion,
where the object moves

with constant speed, and also
nonuniform circular motion,

where the object is speeding
up and/or slowing down
as a function of time.

We will see that a
Cartesian coordinate

system proves awkward for
describing circular motion.

And instead, we will introduce
the so-called polar coordinate

system in terms of
the radius vector

from the origin and its
position angle, which

provides a much more
elegant description
for circular motion.

We will then examine the
dynamics of circular motion

using Newton's second law to
understand what sorts of forces

are required in order to
cause circular motion in both

the uniform and
nonuniform cases.

This will be the first
of several examples

we will see in this course
of constrained motion.

In this case, the constraint
is that the object
moves in a circular path.
